item.title: Connections among attributes
item.description: This page shows the analysis of connections among fields, theories and eras. Philosophy has many fields and has born many theories, if one field connects strongly with one or some specific theories? In other words, if one philosopher belong to one field prefers to research one or specific theories? In addition, did philosophy change a lot with time going on? If some theories or fields just created or being popular in recent years? One weight network is built to analyse the connections among these three attributes. item.title: Core areas
item.description:
In this section we look at several important areas of philosophy:

  • Epistemologists: the critical study of science and scientific knowledge and the study of knowledge in general.

  • Metaphysicians: the fundamental questions of first principles of being, nothingness, identity and change

  • Logicians: the science of reasoning and relationships between ideas

  • Politicaltheorists : the philosophical study of government

  • Aestheticians : deals with questions of beauty and artistic taste

  • Indexsociopoliticalthinkers : focuses to social issues

  • Political : all fields related to politics (broader than the previous two)

  • Ethicists : ethics and ethical codes

item.title: Eras
item.description:
In this part we look at our network from a temporal perspective. We have 9 different timelines: ancient Greece (‘ancientGreek’), pre-christ (‘centuriesBC’), first to tenth centuries (‘1stthrough10thcenturies’), eleventh to fourteenth centuries (‘11ththrough14thcenturies’), fifteenth and sixteenth centuries (‘15thand16thcenturies’), seventeenth century (‘17thcentury’), eighteenth century (‘18thcentury’), nineteenth century (‘19thcentury’), and twentieth century (‘20thcentury’).

We will try to characterize as much as possible each of these periods and see if we can highlight some patterns.

item.title: Regions
item.description:
In this part we look at our network from a spatial perspective. We have 19 different regions : ‘Korean’, ‘Catholicandtheologians’, ‘Finnish’, ‘Slovene’, ‘Italian’, ‘French’, ‘Chinese’, ‘ancientGreek’, ‘Muslim’, ‘Russian’, ‘Japanese’, ‘Canadian’, ‘Romanian’, ‘Indian’, ‘German-language’, ‘Iranian’, ‘American’, ‘peoplefromtheBasqueCountry’, ‘British’.

We will try to characterize as much as possible each of these regions and see if we can highlight some patterns.
